dt: {bc}an element in experience or in artistic representation evoking {d_link|pity|pity:1} or compassion

quotes.t: Many schools at the end of the Depression were poor, but the threadbare nature of Christchurch was almost Dickensian in its {qword}pathos{/qword}.

The struggle back to solvency was arduous, and the stubborn determination and reserves of strength that it called forth from him in his mid-forties made him all at once a figure of considerable {qword}pathos{/qword} and heroism in my eyes, a cross of a kind between Captain Ahab and Willy Loman.
There is a {qword}pathos{/qword} to the deflated certainties that left the Washington lawyer Leonard Garment weeping, inconsolable, outside the Senate chamber as the debate was ended.

et: borrowed from Greek {it}páthos{/it} "experience, misfortune, emotion, condition," noun derivative of a verbal base {it}path-{/it} "experience, undergo, suffer" (present {it}páschō, páschein,{/it} aorist {it}épathon{/it}), going back to {it}*p{sup}(h){/sup}nt{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} zero ablaut grade of a base seen also in {it}pénthos{/it} "grief, sorrow," of uncertain origin

The Greek verb has been compared with Lithuanian {it}kentù, kę͂sti{/it} "to undergo, suffer" (assuming that {it}t{/it} for {it}d{/it} is secondary) and Old Irish {it}césaid{/it} "(s/he) suffers, endures" (< {it}*k{sup}w{/sup}endh-s-{/it}?), though this would require Indo-European {it}*k{sup}w{/sup}endh-,{/it} with a normally unacceptable combination of voiceless stop and voiced aspirated stop in a single root. Alternatively, Greek {it}path-, penth-{/it} has been explained as an idiosyncratic semantic development of Indo-European {it}*bhendh-{/it} "bind" ("be bound" > "suffer"?) (see {et_link|bind:1|bind:1}).
shortdef: an element in experience or in artistic representation evoking pity or compassion
